Package RautSoft.math.nlp

This package contains JNI implementations of two popular optimization packages (Donlp2 and tnc) written originally in C and JNI implementation is due to Professor Lakshmi K. Raut.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
BoundConOpt BoundConOpt: truncated newton bound contrained minimization using gradient information.
DavidsonFletcherPowell Computes the unconstrained minimum of a FunctionOfManyVariables using the modified version of Davidon-Fletcher-Powell algorithm.
DonlpJava DonlpJava is written by Dr. Lakshmi K. Raut as a Java JNI interface to Dr. Peter Spellucci's C implementation of donlp2.
LBFGS This class contains code for the limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (LBFGS) algorithm for large-scale multidimensional unconstrained minimization problems.
Mcsrch This class implements an algorithm for multi-dimensional line search.
SimulatedAnnealing Computes global minimum using the Simulated Annealing algorithm, see Numerical Recipe C++ version for details.
UnconstrainedSingleVariate Finds minimum
 

Exception Summary
LBFGS.ExceptionWithIflag Specialized exception class for LBFGS; contains the iflag value returned by lbfgs.
 

Package RautSoft.math.nlp Description

This package contains JNI implementations of two popular optimization packages (Donlp2 and tnc) written originally in C and JNI implementation is due to Professor Lakshmi K. Raut.

DonlpJava

DonlpJava is written by Dr. Lakshmi K. Raut as a Java JNI interface to Dr. Peter Spellucci's C implementation of donlp2. DonlpJava class has the following methods the ones with a zero at the end means the functions. and the vector x all are indexed from 0.
  • NlpUnConstrainedNumerical() or NlpUnConstrainedNumerical0()
  • NlpMixedConstrainedNumerical() or NlpMixedConstrainedNumerical0()
  • NlpBoundConstrainedNumerical() 

        Min f(x)
        subject to
        xl < x   < xu
        bl < Ax  < bu
        cl < g(x) < cu

Usage Example

        import RautSoft.Interfaces.VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables;
        import RautSoft.Interfaces.FunctionOfManyVariables;
        import RautSoft.math.nlp.DonlpJava;

        public class DonlpEX {
    
        public static void main(String[] args) {
        final int n=2; //number of variables
        final   int nlin = 1; //number of linear constriants
        final    int nonlin = 1;//number of nonlinear constraints
        double []  x0 = {0., 1.0,10.0 }; //first index is 0-index and not used
        FunctionOfManyVariables myObj = new FunctionOfManyVariables(){
        public double value(double [] x){
        return  (Math.pow(x[1]-1.5,2.0)+Math.pow(x[2]+2.5,2) );
        }
        };
        
        VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables Constraints = new VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
        public double [] value(double [] x){
        double [] con = new double[nonlin+1];
        con[0]=0;
        con[1]=x[1] + x[2];
        return con;
        }
        };
        
        //linear constraints
        double [][] gres = new double[n+1][nlin+1];
        
        for (int i=0;i<gres.length;i++)
        for (int j=0;j<gres[0].length;j++) {
        gres[i][j]=0;}
        gres[1][1] = 1.0;
        gres[2][1] = .0;
        
        double [] xLow = {0.0, 0, 0.0};
        double [] xUp =  {0., 100.0,  100.0};
        double [] low = new double [n+nlin+nonlin+1];
        double [] up = new double [n+nlin+nonlin+1];
        for (int i = 1 ; i ≤ n ; i++ ) { low[i]=xLow[i];up[i]=xUp[i];}
        low[3] = up[3]=4;
        low[4] =up[4] = 5; //correponding to one non-linear equality constriant
        /* 0 linear inequality constraints >=0*/
        DonlpJava hwjni = new DonlpJava();
        //To get detailed console output itaktJ should be set to true
        //To get intermediate detailed iteration results te2J=true intermediate steps
        //hwjni.intaktJ=true;
        //hwjni.te2J=true;
        System.out.println("**************************************");
        System.out.println("*  Solving an unconstrianed problem  *");
        System.out.println("*  Min f(x)                          *");
        System.out.println("***************************************");
        hwjni.NlpUnConstrainedNumerical(myObj,x0);
        hwjni.DonlpJNI();
        
        System.out.println(String.format("The  optimal solution for the unconstrained problemis: \n"));
        for (int i=1;i<x0.length;i++) System.out.println(String.format("x*[%d] = %10f",i, x0[i]) );
        System.out.println(String.format("\nThe optimal f* = %f\n", myObj.value(x0)));
        
        System.out.println("*******************************************");
        System.out.println("*  Solving an Bound unconstrianed problem *");
        System.out.println("*  Min f(x)                               *");
        System.out.println("*  subject to                             *");
        System.out.println("*            x_l < x   < x_u              *");
        System.out.println("*******************************************");
        hwjni.NlpBoundConstrainedNumerical(myObj,x0, xLow, xUp);
        hwjni.DonlpJNI();
        System.out.println("The  optimal solution for the unconstrained problemis: \n");
        for (int i=1;i<x0.length;i++) System.out.println(String.format("x*[%d] = %10f",i, x0[i]) );
        System.out.println(String.format("\nThe optimal f* = %f\n", myObj.value(x0)));
        
        System.out.println("**************************************");
        System.out.println("*  Solving a constrianed problem     *");
        System.out.println("*  Min f(x)                          *");
        System.out.println("*  subject to                        *");
        System.out.println("*            x_l < x   < x_u         *");
        System.out.println("*            b_l < Ax  < b_u         *");
        System.out.println("*            c_l < g(x) < c_u        *");
        System.out.println("**************************************");
        hwjni.NlpMixedConstrainedNumerical( myObj,x0,  nlin,nonlin,gres, Constraints, low, up);
        hwjni.DonlpJNI();
        System.out.println("The  optimal solution : \n");
        for (int i=1;i<x0.length;i++) System.out.println(String.format("x*[%d] = %10f",i, x0[i]) );
        System.out.println(String.format("\nThe optimal f* = %f\n", myObj.value(x0)));
        }
        }

Output of the above Program

        **************************************
        *  Solving an unconstrianed problem  *
        *  Min f(x)                          *
        ***************************************
        The  optimal solution for the unconstrained problemis: 

        x*[1] =   1.500000
        x*[2] =  -2.500000

        The optimal f* = 0.000000

        *******************************************
        *  Solving an Bound unconstrianed problem *
        *  Min f(x)                               *
        *  subject to                             *
        *            x_l < x   < x_u              *
        *******************************************
        The  optimal solution for the unconstrained problemis: 

        x*[1] =   1.500000
        x*[2] =   0.000000

        The optimal f* = 6.250000

        **************************************
        *  Solving a constrianed problem     *
        *  Min f(x)                          *
        *  subject to                        *
        *            x_l < x   < x_u         *
        *            b_l < Ax  < b_u         *
        *            c_l < g(x) < c_u        *
        **************************************
        The  optimal solution : 

        x*[1] =   4.000000
        x*[2] =   1.000000

        The optimal f* = 18.500000

BoundConOpt

BoundConOpt is written by Dr. Lakshmi K. Raut as a Java JNI interface to It solves the bound constrained which can be adopted to unconstrained problems of the following type: 

        Min f(x)
        subject to
        xl < x   < xu
It has following main methods
  • BoundConOpt(), this is zero-based indexing unlike the methods in DonlpJava class.

Related Documentations

  • Example1

Other optimization classes in RautSoft application package are all written in 100% java. Here are some of the important ones,

  • DavidsonFletcherPowell, also see Example
  • LBFGS, also see Example
  • SimulatedAnnealing, also see Example
  • UnconstrainedSingleVariate, also see Example
  • More to be added shortly.
